title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
AstraZeneca has revised the efficacy rate for its US Covid-19 vaccine trial from 79 per cent down to 76 per cent as the pharmaceutical group sought to address concerns that it had published incomplete interim data earlier this week. 

The independent US data and safety monitoring board responsible for overseeing the AstraZeneca trial, which involved more than 32,000 participants, objected to the initial data release and called it potentially misleading. 

Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said the monitoring board had sent a “rather harsh note” to him and AstraZeneca following the release of the preliminary trial results.

The board was concerned that the interim data, with a cut-off date of mid-February, would show a more positive efficacy rate, writing that it thought the actual rate could be between 69 and 74 per cent. In response, AstraZeneca accelerated its analysis, which involved examining each additional case to see whether it was really Covid-19. 

The US trial rebuke was the latest controversy facing the Anglo-Swedish drugmaker, which has also been locked in a bitter battle with the EU over accusations it had failed to meet supply targets.

Italy on Wednesday said it had discovered a stockpile of 29m AstraZeneca vaccine doses in a facility in the country, prompting the EU to say the group is “not even close” to delivering the 30m doses of the vaccine it promised the bloc. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • India, one of the world's biggest vaccine producers, has imposed a de facto ban on jab exports as it seeks to prioritise local vaccinations amid an accelerating second wave of coronavirus infections.

  • Brazil's influential business community has hit out at President Jair Bolsonaro's handling of the Covid-19 pandemic as the country's death toll mounts.

  • Angela Merkel reversed course on an Easter shutdown and apologised to Germans for a policy she admitted had been a “mistake”.

  • UK health secretary Matt Hancock told the FT he “can see an end” to the Covid-19 crisis. Travel restrictions, meanwhile, could soon be imposed on trips from France to the UK, Boris Johnson said on Wednesday.

  • National polls show rural Republicans are among the most vaccine-hesitant groups in America. Health officials says young people, in particular, are reluctant to get vaccinated. (FT)

The relentless demands of Covid-19 have left medical workers feeling exhausted and burnt out. “The mental health toll was astronomical,” says one medic at a Pennsylvania hospital. Follow our live blog for the latest and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update email.

In the news

Kamala Harris to lead White House response to border crisis Joe Biden has put vice-president Kamala Harris in charge of US efforts to stop the flow of migrants from Central America over the southern border, as the administration battles to contain the growing political crisis. (FT)

Chinese tech stocks fall sharply on rising regulatory concerns Chinese technology stocks dropped sharply on growing concerns of possible delistings from US exchanges and reported plans by Beijing to take control of companies' user data. The Hong Kong-listed shares of Alibaba, Tencent and Baidu, which debuted in the city this week, all fell heavily on Thursday.

  • Ant Group is demanding a larger slice of commissions from its popular payments platform at the expense of local banks, a move that will help Jack Ma improve the group's valuation after Beijing pulled its planned $37bn IPO last year. (FT)

Powell sees ‘orderly' market adjustment During testimony to the Senate banking committee, Federal Reserve chair Jay Powell sought to stamp out concerns, raised mainly by Republican lawmakers, that the economy could overheat as a result of Joe Biden's $1.9tn stimulus package. (FT)

H&M and Nike face China backlash over Xinjiang stance Global brands H&M and Nike are facing a backlash from Chinese state media and online retailers over historic statements of concern about forced labour in the country's western Xinjiang region. China's Ministry of Commerce on Thursday called accusations of forced labour in the cotton-producing region “imaginary”.

  • Facebook has uncovered a sophisticated espionage campaign conducted by Chinese hackers that tried to trick pro-Uyghur activists and dissidents around the world into downloading malicious software that would allow surveillance of their devices. (FT)

Tribune Publishing sticks with hedge fund bid despite higher offer The board of Tribune Publishing, the owner of the Chicago Tribune and New York Daily News, has recommended shareholders back a takeover offer by Alden, a New York hedge fund, rather than a higher offer from a Baltimore-based hotel magnate who wants to run the papers as non-profits. (FT)

Financing for Texas wind power in disarray after winter storm Renewable energy investors are reassessing their plans in Texas after last month's winter storm froze some wind power projects and left their complex financing arrangements in a shambles. (FT)

Suez Canal clearance could take ‘weeks' Rescuers have warned that the Suez Canal could remain blocked by a grounded giant container ship for “weeks”, raising fears of significant disruption to global trade. In normal times the Suez Canal handles more than 10 per cent of global seaborne trade and a similar amount of petroleum shipments. (FT)

North Korea conducts second weapons test in a week North Korea has conducted its second significant weapons test in the past week. The North Korean military fired two short-range ballistic missiles, which flew about 450km and reached an altitude of 60km, into the waters off its eastern coastline on Thursday morning. (FT)

The day ahead

Tech chiefs testify Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg will answer lawmakers' questions alongside Google's Sundar Pichai and Twitter's Jack Dorsey on the disinformation plaguing online platforms. Social media groups are under pressure to root out vaccine misinformation. (FT)

EU vaccine exports summit European Union leaders meet to discuss controversial new rules aimed at restricting the export of vaccines. US president Joe Biden will dial in to the summit. (FT)

Economic data US GDP data for the fourth quarter is out today as well as initial jobless claims, which are expected to remain at the pandemic's lowest levels. The Treasury is also looking to offload $62bn of 7-year notes, an auction investors will be watching closely. (FT)

Biden press conference The US president will attend his first official press conference since taking office 64 days ago. (FT)

Tokyo Olympic torch relay The Olympic torch began its 121-day journey in Fukushima as Japan tries to boost confidence ahead of the delayed event. (FT, ABC News)

What else we're reading

Corporate money trickles back to Republicans Several large US companies, including Cigna, Intel and T-Mobile, made the maximum legal contributions to vehicles supporting Republican candidates in February, according to the latest monthly Federal Election Commission filings. The payments are an early sign that corporate America is returning to the GOP after deserting it following January's attacks on the US Capitol. (FT)

Clean tech 2:0 From battery storage technologies to sustainable aviation fuel, lab-grown meat to low-carbon concrete, investors are rushing to put money behind companies fighting climate change. Analysts say this time is different, with entrepreneurs backed by deep-pocketed corporate investors. (FT)

The revered tech investor that backed Greensill General Atlantic, the private equity group that spotted the potential in Alibaba, is known as one of the smartest investors in the technology sector. But after investing in Greensill Capital, the supply-chain financier which is now insolvent, its reputation has taken a hit. (FT)

Covid jabs are at the sharp end of political risk Anyone running a pharma company these days, or investing in one, must take notice of political risk, writes Gillian Tett. Questions such as “Will there be a trade war?”, “How can we measure populism?” and “Is politics in the region looking stable?” are increasingly crucial. (FT)

Iraqi dreams of democracy fade with arrests of journalists Since 2003, Iraqis have carved out a “small space” to speak out, says Diyari Salih, a lecturer at Baghdad's Mustansiriyah University. But he warned that the supreme judicial council's use of 1969 legislation to choke dissent “confirms that Saddam [Hussein's] mentality is still working”. (FT)

How to nurture positive change For the second instalment of our Leaders' Lessons series, we asked top executives: how are you making sure the positive — and accelerated — changes of the past year are embedded permanently? (FT)

Video of the day

How Redditors took on Wall Street | FT Film Retail investors gathered on Reddit's r/WallStreetBets forum to take on short selling hedge funds, and sent shares in video game retailer GameStop and several other “meme stocks” on a rollercoaster ride. How did the short squeeze unfold, what does it mean for hedge funds and what happens next? (FT)

Source: Gordon Smith, Jennifer Creery and Emily Goldberg 2021 'FirstFT: Today's top stories' FT.com 25 March. Used under licence from the Financial Times. © The Financial Times Limited 2021. All Rights Reserved.
